messages: 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:18): Don't you love the integer constants in webrtc?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:19): Oh god, seriously?  Man, that means I gotta yell at someone.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:19): Then I don't have to
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:27): I'm confused as to why the PeerConnection constants aren't all sequential.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:27): Is it meant to allow someone to compose them all into a bitfield?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:28): Also: Hm, I appear to have gained AC permissions in the W3C.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:29): Or this page is badly permissioned, and has horrible UI.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:29): (It thinks I'm T.V. Raman.)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:29): i always have trouble finding PeerConnection-related specs; searches never find anything but lists
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:30): The webrtc homepage has useful links.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:32): what's the deal with these giganto parameter tables? what possible use are they?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:35): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: maybe the numbers map to protocol numbers, in a (somewhat strange) attempt to avoid having to translate?
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:35): (don't recall anything about the underlying protocol)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:35): Argh, I'm going to compromise my principles and send an HTML email so I can get decent ins/del-like formatting.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:35): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: I suspect that's the case.  It's lazy design, though.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:37): http://dev.w3.org/2011/webrtc/editor/images/media-stream-1.png random image in spec is ... somewhat startling (and not terribly enlightening)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:38): Agree.  Also, somewhat fuzzy, indicating poor scaling.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:38): Which is odd, since the check marks are well-scaled.

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:38): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: it smells like this spec was made by someone who's only recently read the filesystem API spec, which is in much the same style (both the spec style, and the use of constant ints)
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:39): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb, usually it shows AC-member-only forms as if you were the AC rep, with a note saying "you can't do this"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:39): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: The use of int constants is very common among anyone who primarily programs in C++ or Java (that is, most browser devs).

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:40): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: Yeah, that's usual.  I *appear* to have the ability, though, to make Google leave the WebRTC group.  The checkboxes and submit button are all enabled.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:41): give it a shot, what could possibly go wrong? :P
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:41): what's the worst that could happen (two weeks later Google withdraws from the w3c and an asteroid strikes the planet)
bdf7d7409da19264fa0c4bf6b4f2d0cc (23:42): a wild pack of lawyers appear! they use beatdown on 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb. it's super effective!

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:42): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: one would hope that anyone designing a web API would have a good deal of experience with existing APIs and current design practices, though
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:42): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: One would hope, yes.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:42): (for whatever vain level of "hope")
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:42): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: One would be very, very disappointed.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:43): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: on the other hand, the editors list on this spec reduces one's hope
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:43): (nothing personal to those names; referring to the company list, except for Mozilla)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:44): (i assume those constants weren't in there when hixie wrote the initial draft?)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:44): (never mind the fs-api-ization of the whole thing)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:45): at least where it really matters (eg. method algorithms), it hasn't gone that way
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:48): (i'm meaning to compare to the "file api: directories and system" spec, not File API; i suppose i should refer to the former as "file-system" or something)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (23:49): roman numeral hostnames? heh
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:50): All right, complaint about constants sent.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:56): https://twitter.com/#!/jarrednicholls/status/147804488848261120
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:56): "I just added support for XMLHttpRequest.responseXML to handle HTML documents http://t.co/HaRiuLoa http://t.co/wipNrLVu #WebKit"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:57): Yessssssss
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:57): so already landed in Firefox and shipping in FF10
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:57): and now Webkit too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:57): annevk: ‚Üë
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:57): With that in place, it's finally easy to do an easy upgrade to ajax-based navigation by swapping out sections.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:58): this doesn't add support for json yet, I don't think
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:18): huh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:19): someone points out that the <input type=""> sections don't actually include the keyword needed to trigger them
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:19): that's kinda silly of me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:19): i wonder where to put them
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:20): in the heading? ("Text state (type=text) and Search state (type=search)") In the first paragraph? In examples?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:20): wouldn't be bad to add examples in general, i guess
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:20): I like the headings.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:20): So you can see them in the TOC easily.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:20): yeah, that's probably reasonable
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:20): curses
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:21): Why curses?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:21): means work
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:21): Come here and I'll pat you on the head.  Specs is hard.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:21): don't i know it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:22): "(type=hidden)" or "(type="hidden")"?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:22): The first.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:22): (type=hidden) or ("type=hidden") ?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:23): Hm.  I think the first.
